, the legendary journalist who covered World War II and the Cold War, was a master of the television interview. He had an uncanny ability to draw out his subjects, whether they were politicians or celebrities.
Murrow’s interviews are still studied today by journalism students as examples of how to conduct a good interview. But what made him so successful? What did he do that other reporters didn’t?
In this article, we’ll look at some of the techniques that Murrow used to get such great results from his interviews. We’ll also examine some of the mistakes that other reporters make when conducting interviews.
The first thing you need to know about Murrow is that he was a perfectionist. He wanted to be sure that every word he said was perfect. This meant that he spent hours preparing for each interview.
He would read everything he could find on his subject, including books, magazines, newspapers, and even letters written by the person. He would then write down questions based on what

, the inventor of Kevlar, died on June 18 at age 90.
Kevlar is a synthetic fiber that is five times stronger than steel and used in bulletproof vests, helmets, and other protective gear. It was developed by DuPont scientist Stephanie Kwolek in 1965. She was awarded the National Medal of Technology and Innovation in 2014 for her work.

Day is an annual event, observed every year on May 22.

and Nick Jonas are engaged
Priyanka Chopra and Nick Jonas have announced their engagement. The couple, who have been dating since May 2018, got engaged in London on Saturday (01.12.18).
The 'Quantico' star took to Instagram to share a picture of her ring, which features a large diamond surrounded by smaller stones. She captioned the image: "Taken.. With all my heart and soul."
Nick also shared a photo of his fiancée wearing the ring, writing: "Future Mrs. Jonas. My heart. My love."
The pair were first spotted together at the Met Gala in New York City in May, and they made their red carpet debut as a couple at the 2018 MET Gala.
They then went public with their romance when they attended the Beauty and the Beast premiere in Los Angeles in June.

, ASC, AFC
Darius Khondji is a French cinematographer who has worked on many films in the United States and France. He was born in Tehran, Iran, but moved to Paris at an early age. He studied photography at the Ecole Nationale Supérieure Louis Lumière and began his career as a still photographer for magazines such as Elle and Vogue. In 1987 he became a cinematographer and has since shot over 50 feature films. His work includes The City of Your Final Destination (2009), The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008), The Last Mistress (2007), The Illusionist (2006), The Good Shepherd (2006), The Da Vinci Code (2006), Intolerable Cruelty (2003), Cold Mountain (2003), The Talented Mr. Ripley (1999), The Horse Whisperer (19

, the president of Bolivia, has been in power since 2006. He is a former coca farmer and union leader who was elected to office on a platform of social justice and anti-imperialism.
Bolivia’s economy is based largely on natural resources, including mining, agriculture, and hydrocarbons. The country is rich in natural gas, but it lacks the infrastructure to export it. As a result, Bolivia exports only about 15 percent of its gas reserves.
The government of Evo Morales has nationalized many industries, including oil and gas, telecommunications, electricity, and water. It also controls the banking system.
Morales has been criticized for his authoritarian style of leadership. In 2013, he won reelection with more than 60 percent of the vote.

, the Mexican artist who was married to Diego Rivera, is one of the most famous artists in history. She was a painter and a political activist. Her paintings are often self-portraits that depict her life and her struggles with polio, miscarriages, and other health issues.
Frida Kahlo was born on July 6, 1907, in Mexico City. She was the daughter of a German photographer and a Mexican mother. As a child, she suffered from polio, which left her right leg shorter than her left. She also had a broken spine and a collapsed lung. These injuries caused her pain throughout her life.
Kahlo's father died when she was six years old. When she was 18, she met Diego Rivera, an artist who would become her husband. They were married in 1929. The couple divorced in 1939, but they remained friends until Rivera's death in 1957.

on the Occupy Movement

He has written extensively about the Occupy movement, which he sees as an important step toward a new global political awakening. In this video, he discusses his views on the movement with Amy Goodman of Democracy Now!

American Dance Theater, New York City Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera are among the companies that will perform at Lincoln Center in 2018-19.
The Metropolitan Opera will present its first production of "La Fille du Régiment" since 1976.
Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will celebrate its 60th anniversary with a season that includes two world premieres.
New York City Ballet will mark its 50th anniversary at the David H. Koch Theater with a series of special events.
The Metropolitan Opera will present its first production of "La Fille du Régiment" since 1976, starring soprano Diana Damrau as Marie and tenor Juan Diego Flórez as Tonio. The opera is based on a libretto by Eugène Scribe and Jean-François Bayard, which was adapted from a play by Pierre-Ange Vieillard. It will be conducted by Fabio Luisi and directed by Bartlett Sher. Performances begin Sept. 24.

, the 2010 Olympic figure skating champion from South Korea, has been named as a member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) Athletes’ Commission.
The IOC announced on Monday that Kim was one of five new members to join the commission, which is made up of 10 athletes and five non-athletes. The other four new members are: American swimmer Dara Torres, Canadian ice hockey player Hayley Wickenheiser, Australian rower Kim Brennan and British fencer James Williams.
Kim, who won gold at the Vancouver Games in 2010, will serve a four-year term on the commission. She is the first Korean athlete to be elected to the IOC Athletes’ Commission.
“I am honored to have been elected by my fellow athletes to represent them on the IOC Athletes’ Commission,” said Kim. “It is an incredible privilege to be able to contribute to the development of sport and the Olympic Movement.”

's son Jaycee Chan arrested for drug use
Jackie Chan's son, Jaycee Chan, has been arrested in Beijing on suspicion of using drugs. The 32-year-old was detained by police after a raid at his home and is being held in custody while investigations continue.
Jaycee Chan Photo: REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
The actor's father, Jackie Chan, said he was "very angry" about the arrest and that it had caused him great pain.
He added that he would not comment further until the investigation was complete.
Chan, who is one of China's most famous actors, has starred in more than 150 films since making his debut in 1982. He has also appeared in Hollywood movies including Rush Hour and Shanghai Noon.

was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize. She was also the first person to win two Nobel Prizes, and the only person to win them in different sciences.
Marie Sklodowska Curie was born on November 7, 1867, in Warsaw, Poland. Her father, Wladyslaw, was a teacher of mathematics and physics at a local school. Her mother, Bronislawa, taught music. Marie's older sister, Bronia, was also a scientist.
Marie attended a prestigious all-girls school in Warsaw. In 1891, she graduated with honors from the University of Warsaw. She then moved to Paris, France, where she studied under French physicist Henri Becquerel.
In 1895, Marie married Pierre Curie, another French physicist. The couple worked together on research projects. They discovered that certain elements emit radiation when they are exposed to light. This discovery earned them the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903.

and the Communist Manifesto
Karl Marx was a German philosopher, economist, historian, political theorist, sociologist, journalist and revolutionary socialist. Born in Trier to a middle-class family, he later studied political economy and Hegelian philosophy. As an adult, Marx became stateless and spent much of his life in exile, living in Brussels, Paris, London, and other cities, where he continued to develop his thought in collaboration with German thinker Friedrich Engels. In 1848, he co-founded a communist society known as the International Workingmen's Association. His work has been said to form the basis of modern communism, while his subsequent atheism has led him to be described as one of the fathers of secular humanism.
Marx's ideas about society, economics and politics have been widely influential, but they have also been highly controversial, both when he was alive and after his death. He held that human societies progress through class struggle; this theory is

: Trump’s ‘Fake News Awards’ Are A Fake
Rachel Maddow took a look at President Donald Trump’s “fake news awards” and found that they were, in fact, fake.
“The president of the United States is going to give out fake news awards,” she said on her show Monday night. “He’s going to give them out tonight.”
Maddow noted that the White House had not released any details about the event, but that it was being held at 6 p.m. ET. She also pointed out that the White House did not release a list of nominees for the awards.
“So we don’t know who he’s giving these awards to,” she said. “We don’t know what criteria he’s using to decide who gets an award. We don’t know how many awards there are going to be. We don’t know if this is going to be a one-time thing or if this is going to become a regular thing. We don’t know if

's Food Revolution Day
Jamie Oliver is a British chef, restaurateur and media personality. He is the founder of the food campaign group, The Food Revolution Network, which works to educate people about food and nutrition. In 2010, he was named one of Time magazine’s 100 most influential people in the world.
Oliver has written several books on cooking and healthy eating, including his best-selling cookbook, “Jamie’s Italy.” His television series include “The Naked Chef,” “Jamie’s Kitchen” and “Jamie’s School Dinners.”
In 2010, Oliver launched the Food Revolution Campaign, an organization that seeks to improve school lunches and raise awareness about childhood obesity. In 2013, he launched the Food Revolution Network, a nonprofit organization dedicated to improving public health through education.

was a British economist whose ideas have had a profound impact on the theory and practice of modern macroeconomics, as well as on economic policy and political discourse. He is widely considered to be one of the most influential economists of the 20th century.
Keynes's ideas are often credited with having fundamentally changed the way governments view the role of fiscal and monetary policy in combating recession and unemployment. His ideas also influenced the work of many leading economists, including Milton Friedman, Friedrich Hayek, James Meade, Joan Robinson, Paul Samuelson, Robert Solow, and George Stigler.
Keynes's book The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money (1936) was an attempt to explain the causes of business cycles and high levels of unemployment. In it he argued that inadequate spending can lead to prolonged periods of high unemployment because deficient demand will cause producers to cut back production, which will cause

, the first African American to earn a Ph.D. in physics, was born on this day in 1852.
Bouchet was born in New Haven, Connecticut, and attended Yale University, where he earned his bachelor’s degree in 1874. He then went on to study at Johns Hopkins University, where he received his master’s degree in 1876 and his doctorate in 1886.
After graduating from Johns Hopkins, Bouchet taught at Howard University for two years before becoming an instructor of physics at Fisk University in Nashville, Tennessee. In 1890, he became the chair of physics at the newly founded Atlanta University (now Clark Atlanta University).
In 1896, Bouchet became the first African American to receive a Ph.D. in physics when he graduated from the University of Berlin. He also served as president of the National Association of Colored Women from 1900-1903.

's Code, the first written code of law in history, was created around 1750 BC. It is a collection of laws that were inscribed on a stone tablet and discovered by archeologists in 1901. The code was named after King Hammurabi of Babylon, who ruled from 1792 to 1750 BC.
The code was found in the ruins of the ancient city of Susa, which was located in what is now Iran. The code was written in cuneiform script on a black diorite stele, or stone slab. The code consists of 282 laws that cover a wide range of topics, including family relations, property rights, business transactions, criminal punishments and military matters. The code also includes a section on women's rights, which was unusual for the time period.

once said, “The only source of knowledge is experience.”
I’ve been a professional photographer for over 20 years. I started out as an assistant to a commercial photographer in New York City and then moved on to shooting my own work. I have worked with many different types of clients including advertising agencies, magazines, corporations, non-profits, and individuals. My work has appeared in numerous publications including The New York Times, Time Magazine, Newsweek, People Magazine, Sports Illustrated, and many others.
My photography has taken me all over the world. I have traveled to over 50 countries and lived in several of them. I have shot assignments in places like China, India, Russia, South America, Europe, Africa, and the Middle East. I have also spent time living in Japan, Thailand, and Mexico.
I am currently based in Los Angeles where I live with my wife and two children.

(1770-1827) was a German composer and pianist. He is considered one of the greatest composers in history, and his influence on Western music has been profound.
Beethoven's father was a tenant farmer who also worked as a musician. His mother was a singer. When he was 11 years old, Beethoven began studying piano with his father. At age 14, he went to Vienna to study with Haydn. In 1792, he became the assistant organist at St. Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna. In 1795, he became the court organist for Prince Lichnowsky. In 1796, he married Johanna van Beethoven. They had two children together, but she died in 1815.
In 1803, Beethoven moved to Vienna, where he lived until his death. During this time, he composed many works, including nine symphonies, five piano concertos, 16

, the first black woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, has died at age 88.
Morrison's son Slade said his mother died peacefully at Montefiore Medical Center in New York on Monday night. He did not say what caused her death.
The author of "Beloved," ''Song of Solomon" and other novels was a pioneer for black women writers. She won the Pulitzer Prize in 1988 for "Beloved."
She also wrote the libretto for an opera based on "The Bluest Eye," which she adapted from her own novel.

, the most decorated Olympian of all time, has announced his retirement from competitive swimming.
Phelps, 28, won a record-tying 18 gold medals at the London Games and is the first athlete to win the same individual event at three consecutive Olympics. He also holds the world record in the 100-meter butterfly and 200-meter individual medley.
"I'm not going to lie, it was hard," Phelps said on "Good Morning America." "It was something I had to think about for a long time. It was something that I wanted to do for a very long time. But I just felt like it was time."
Phelps will continue to train with coach Bob Bowman and compete in the U.S. Masters Swimming circuit.

, 1947-2006

, CNN's chief international correspondent and host of "Amanpour," will moderate a discussion with former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and former National Security Adviser Stephen Hadley on the future of U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East.

, the Argentine soccer legend who led his country to victory in the 1986 World Cup, was arrested on Sunday after being found asleep in a hotel room with two women.
The former star player and coach was taken into custody by police in Buenos Aires after he was discovered in bed with two women at the Hotel Alvear Palace, according to local media reports.
Maradona, 50, was charged with public drunkenness and could face up to six months in jail if convicted. He was released from custody later that day.
"I'm not going to say anything about this," Maradona told reporters outside the hotel. "I'm very sorry for my family."
He added: "I'm not going to say anything else because I don't want to make any more trouble."

’s 1939 contract with MGM
Judy Garland’s 1939 contract with MGM. The document, signed by Louis B. Mayer and dated 28th August 1939, is for a period of seven years at $750 per week. It also includes an option to renew the contract for another year at $1,000 per week. The contract was signed in New York City on the same day that Garland made her first screen test for MGM. She had been discovered by talent scout Johnny Hyde while performing in vaudeville shows in New York.

, Patriots agree to 2-year contract extension
Tom Brady and the New England Patriots have agreed to a two-year contract extension that will keep the quarterback with the team through the 2019 season.
The deal was first reported by ESPN's Adam Schefter on Monday night.
Brady, who turns 41 in August, is coming off his sixth Super Bowl title and has led the Patriots to 16 playoff appearances in 18 seasons. He has won three MVP awards and been named to 13 Pro Bowls.
He is also the NFL's all-time leader in passing yards (71,279), touchdown passes (520) and passer rating (96.9).

and Kanye West are expecting their third child via surrogate, according to multiple reports.

Kardashian and West have two children together: daughter North, 4, and son Saint, 2.
In September, Kardashian revealed she was suffering from placenta accreta, which occurs when the placenta grows too deeply into the uterine wall. She said she would not be able to carry another child herself.

's 1957 Pink Cadillac
Elvis Presley's 1957 Pink Cadillac is a 1957 Cadillac Eldorado Biarritz convertible. It was purchased by Elvis in 1957 and he used it for the next two years, until he bought a new pink Cadillac in 1959. The car was then sold to a friend of Elvis', who kept it until 1968 when it was sold to another collector. In 2004, the car was sold at auction for $320,000.
The car has been restored to its original condition and is now on display at Graceland.

's 'Thriller' is the most popular music video of all time
Michael Jackson's "Thriller" has been named the most popular music video of all time. The 1983 clip, which was directed by John Landis and featured a zombie-like dance routine, beat out videos from artists like Madonna, Rihanna and Beyoncé to take the top spot in a new ranking by Vevo.
The video for "Thriller," which was released on Nov. 2, 1983, has been viewed more than 1 billion times on YouTube. It also holds the record for the most views in a single day, with 765,000 views on Dec. 2, 2009.
Vevo, which is owned by Google and Universal Music Group, compiled its list using data from YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and VEVO.com. The rankings were based on total views, shares, likes, comments and reactions.

, MD, PhD, is a physician and anthropologist who has worked in Haiti for more than 25 years. He is the founding director of Partners In Health (PIH), an international health organization that provides direct medical services and supports national health systems to combat poverty-related diseases in resource-poor settings around the world. Dr. Farmer is also chair of the Department of Global Health and Social Medicine at Harvard Medical School and chief of the Division of Global Health Equity at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.
Dr. Farmer is the author of Pathologies of Power: Health, Human Rights, and the New War on the Poor (University of California Press, 2003) and Infections and Inequalities: The Modern Plagues (University of California Press, 2001). His most recent book, To Repair the World: Paul Farmer Speaks to the Next Generation, was published by University of California Press in 2013.

is a graphic designer, artist and educator. He has been the recipient of more than 200 awards, including the AIGA Gold Medal, the National Design Award for Lifetime Achievement from the Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, the first ever Presidential Design Award, and the Fulbright Lifetime Achievement Medal.
Glaser’s work is in the permanent collections of museums worldwide, including the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris, and the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam. His clients have included American Express, The Atlantic Monthly, CBS Records, Esquire, Harper’s Bazaar, The New York Times, NBC, Penguin Books, Sony Music, and Wired magazine.
He is the author of 17 books on design, art and culture, including Graphic Design: The New Basics (Harry N. Abrams, 200

, the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, disappeared in 1937 while attempting to circumnavigate the globe.
Amelia Earhart was born on July 24, 1897, in Atchison, Kansas. She grew up in Kansas and Oklahoma, where she developed a love of flying. In 1928, she became the first woman to fly across the Atlantic Ocean as a passenger. Two years later, she set a women's altitude record by flying to an altitude of 14,000 feet. In 1932, she became the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California. In 1935, she became the first person to fly solo from Mexico City to Newark, New Jersey.
In 1937, Earhart attempted to become the first person to fly around the world. On June 1, 1937, she took off from Oakland, California, with her navigator Fred Noonan. They were never seen again

, the first man to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, was born on this day in 1902.
Lindbergh’s flight from New York to Paris took 33 hours and 30 minutes. He landed at Le Bourget Field near Paris on May 21, 1927.
The plane he flew was called The Spirit of St. Louis. It was a single-engine monoplane built by Ryan Airlines.
Lindbergh received the $25,000 Orteig Prize for his achievement.

's Fearless is a 2006 Chinese-Hong Kong martial arts film directed by Ronny Yu and starring Jet Li. The film was released in China on December 1, 2006, and in the United States on January 5, 2007. It is based on the life of Huo Yuanjia, a real-life Chinese martial artist who founded the Jin Wu Sports Federation.
The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its action sequences and others criticizing its storyline. It was nominated for Best Action Choreography at the 2007 MTV Movie Awards.
In 1910, Huo Yuanjia (Jet Li) returns to his hometown of Beijing after spending several years in Japan learning martial arts. -Yo Ma, the world’s most famous cellist, is coming to town.
The 62-year-old musician will perform at the University of Notre Dame on Oct. 19 as part of his “Bach Project,” a tour that has him performing all six Bach cello suites in 36 cities around the world.
Ma will be joined by pianist Kathryn Stott and violinist Nicholas Cords for the performance, which will take place at 7:30 p.m. in the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center. Tickets are $45-$85 and can be purchased online or by calling (574) 631-2800.
Ma has been playing the cello since he was four years old and has performed with some of the greatest musicians of our time, including Itzhak Perlman, Isaac Stern, Mstislav Rostropovich, Jessye Norman, Wynton Marsalis, James Levine, Sir Simon Rattle, Z

's Needle, London
Cleopatra's Needle is a 73-foot tall granite obelisk that was originally erected in Heliopolis, Egypt. It was given to the British government by the Khedive of Egypt as a gift for Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee in 1887. The needle was transported to England and placed on a stone pedestal at the entrance to the Thames Embankment. In 1972, it was moved to its current location near the north end of the Serpentine Bridge in Hyde Park.

Library > Events > The Science of Mind: A Conversation with Dr. Joe Dispenza
The Science of Mind: A Conversation with Dr. Joe Dispenza
Dr. Joe Dispenza is an author, lecturer, researcher, and educator who has studied human potential for over 20 years. He’s taught thousands of people how to rewire their brains and recondition their bodies to make lasting changes. His workshops have been attended by people from all walks of life, including those in corporate America, the entertainment industry, and professional athletes.
In this conversation, Dr. Dispenza will discuss his new book, You Are the Placebo: Making Your Mind Matter, which explores the science behind the mind-body connection. He will also share insights on how we can use our thoughts to create a healthier body and a happier life.

has been named the 2019 Laureus World Sportsman of the Year.
The Spaniard, who won his 19th Grand Slam title at the Australian Open in January, was presented with the award by former tennis player and current Laureus Academy Member Martina Navratilova on Monday night in Monaco.
Nadal beat out fellow nominees Lewis Hamilton, Novak Djokovic, Tiger Woods and Simone Biles to win the award.
"It's a great honor for me," Nadal said. "I am very happy to be here. I want to thank all my team, my family, my friends, my fans. It's an amazing feeling."
Nadal is the first Spanish athlete to win the award since Barcelona FC midfielder Andres Iniesta took home the honor in 2011.
The 33-year-old also won the ATP World Tour Player of the Year award earlier this month.

has been named the 2017 Laureus World Sportsman of the Year.

Federer beat Formula One driver Lewis Hamilton and Olympic champion Usain Bolt to the prize.
"It's an incredible honour," said Federer. "I'm very happy to be here tonight. I've had a great year, but it's not just me. It's also my team, my family, my fans, my country.
"I'm so happy to share this moment with them."
Federer, who is now 35, added: "I hope I can keep going for another five years or more. I'm really looking forward to the next few years."

, Untitled (2013). Courtesy of the artist and Night Gallery.
Petra Cortright’s new paintings at Night Gallery are a continuation of her ongoing series of digital works that began in 2009. The exhibition is titled “Untitled” because it consists of untitled paintings, but also because the show is an attempt to strip away all titles and labels from the work. In this way, the paintings become more about process than product.
Cortright’s paintings are made using a computer program called Painter, which allows users to create images by drawing with a mouse. The resulting images look like they were created by hand, but they are actually generated by a machine. This creates a tension between the human and the mechanical, as well as between the physical and the virtual.
The paintings in the show are mostly abstract, but some have recognizable shapes. They are all based on photographs taken by Cortright herself, and she has used these photos as source material for other artworks in the

's Spago Las Vegas
Wolfgang Puck’s Spago Las Vegas is a modern Italian restaurant located in the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace. The restaurant features an open kitchen, where guests can watch as chefs prepare their dishes. The menu includes appetizers such as lobster bisque and fried calamari, pasta dishes like spaghetti with clams and pesto, and entrees including filet mignon and sea bass. The restaurant also offers a selection of wines from around the world.

’s ‘Interstellar’ Gets a New Trailer
Christopher Nolan's Interstellar has been one of the most anticipated films of 2014, and now we have our first look at the film in its entirety. The new trailer for the sci-fi epic was released today (October 3), and it gives us a much better idea of what to expect from the movie.
The trailer opens with Matthew McConaughey's character Cooper saying, "We used to look up at the sky and wonder at our place in the stars, now we just look down and worry about our place in the dirt." It then cuts to a shot of Earth as seen from space, before showing off some of the amazing visual effects that will be on display throughout the film.
Nolan is known for his use of practical effects, but he also uses CGI when necessary. In this case, the CGI looks pretty spectacular, and it helps to create an otherworldly feel.

Sol LeWitt was a pioneer of conceptual art and one of the most influential artists of the twentieth century. His work is in the collections of major museums around the world, including MoMA, the Guggenheim Museum, and Tate Modern. This book features more than 250 works from throughout his career, including early drawings, wall drawings, sculptures, and paintings.

, the founder of Chinese social media giant Weibo, has been detained by police in Beijing.
The company said on its official account that Mr Zhang was being held for questioning over alleged violations of laws and regulations.
Weibo is China's equivalent of Twitter, with more than 380 million users.
It is one of the country's most popular social media platforms, but it has come under increasing pressure from authorities.
In recent months, the government has stepped up efforts to control online content, including blocking access to foreign websites such as Facebook and Google.
Mr Zhang founded Weibo in 2009 and became its chief executive officer in 2014. He also serves as chairman of Sina Corporation, which owns Weibo.
He is a member of the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee and the CPC Central Committee Political Bureau.

is a man of many talents, but he's not the only one in his family with acting chops. His son Indio has been making waves in Hollywood since 2015 when he made his debut on the big screen alongside his dad in The Judge.
